Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2022
Data:
We have two of these, now. The new one is in my office with cherry furniture. The wife bought a nice enough unit at Target, but the weekly dusting exercise diminished not. When I saw the Blue Air on a deep discount, I ordered one. Not only is it quieter (per dB meter), but there's significantly less dust. Hopefully, it will perform as well and as long as our other unit, which has been rock solid in continuous use for several years. With the older unit, it was many months before it signaled a filter change. New filters are cheap, and the knock-off brand we use seems to work well.

That's not to say there's no bats in this belfry. First, with a cloth cover of the corrugated filter, it is a little delicate. You pick it up by the cloth cover, and risk damaging the filter. I try to pick it up by the white plastic top, and usually manage to rotate it 1/16 of a turn, releasing the filter assembly to tumble across the floor, releasing the accumulated dust. It does tend to teach the careless to care.
Changing filters isn't the easiest, as it generally takes two of us to pull the cloth pre-filter over the HEPA filter without creasing the fins. And, after an episode you will certainly only do once in your life, never decide to sterilize the cloth cover by washing it in hot water followed by a hot dryer. You'd think I would have learned my lesson the time I did that to my expensive cashmere sweater, turning it into a garment for my toddler. Did I forget to mention? Wash the cloth pre-filter under a cold tap, and allow it to air dry.
Final observation. The first Blue Air came with a blue filter. This one is black, with a spare blue. Perfect, as I needed an extra cover to replace the one I cashmered. I like the black better. As it accumulates dust, it turns into an attractive mottled gray. The blue one doesn't look so good as it accumulates dust, with ugly streaks where the dog wiped his nose (we've learned to keep the air cleaner in a corner to keep it upright).
However, the ugliness that the blue one becomes may be a blessing as it encourages more frequent cleaning. As I vacuum the house, I see it needs cleaning so I'll take an upholstery attachment to it. Shortly, there's a screech, and I'll find myself vacuuming it outside. Being cylindrical with a cloth cover over paper fins, it's not the easiest thing to vacuum, and nothing but washing seems to help the dog snot problem. But I suppose there's worse things the dog could wipe on it.
The down sides are pretty inconsequential to me. OK, I need to learn to be delicate with something for once. The important things are it makes it easier to breathe. The house is easier to clean. And it seems to work, day after day for years, without making a lot of noise, smoke, or requiring a carpet cleaner who specializes in blue goo. As well, at least the dog doesn't wipe his nose on the expensive drapes.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2024
Data:
I am reviewing the BlueAir 211i Max and 411i Max series in this review as I bought both - one for living room and one for bedroom. Bottom line, these are very impressive units and for the price I am impressed and pleased with each for functionality and effectiveness. I think the aesthetics of it are pleasing as well. It looks nicer than a black box wheezing in your room.
Pros for the BlueAir series. very very quiet. On auto maintenance mode - you can't hear the thing. These are smart machines. You can monitor every aspect of your air quality through the app. You can adjust the control lights from off to bright. It tracks months of air quality data for the room it is in by month, week, day. You can adjust from sleep mode, auto, and 3 fan speeds using the app remotely. It tells you how much filter life is left. It tells you the outside air quality and compares to your inside.
Example of its effectiveness; I was sautéing some Italian sausage and onions, the unit detected the particles and immediately went into high mode for about 5 minutes until all the odor was eliminated and then went back to silent. The front LED bar changes from Blue to Green, orange and red depending on the air quality while at the same time adjusting the fan speed to address the corresponding level of air quality indicated. Same thing happened when smoking some meat on the back patio. I left the door open to bring in the food, the unit detected the smoke and the front LED went red. After closing the door, it ran on high mode until the LED indicators began to regress back to blue and the fan speed decreasing accordingly until all the smoke odor was eliminated from the room.
Cons for the BlueAir product. It is a bit pricier than other options - but for all the differences - so far, I feel the Blue Air product is definitely worth the price difference, for me at least.
What I have not addressed: the longivity of the products; the life of the filter; ease of maintaining; Both of my purchases are within the first month;

Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2018
Data:
Have had it a week. It arrived on time in perfect condition. It came with 2 prefilters (large long stretchy socks that slip over the main filter). One was sky blue and the other black. I'm using the sky blue right now. It's easy to slip it over the filter which is the lower part of the machine.
It's very attractive. It's lightweight. It's so quiet on first setting you don't know it's on, but I wonder how much filtering it would do. It's fairly quiet on second setting, you do notice that one, but not unpleasantly. It's somewhat loud on third setting, definitely noticeable, especially when I'm trying to compose or listen to music or watching a movie, it can become annoying. Doesn't bother me as much when I'm resting, reading, or trying to sleep. But it's not as loud as some of the Holmes or other brands I've tried over the years.
It's easy to vacuum the prefilter (as I said, the stretchy sock that slips over the filter). With a brush attachment to my vacuum I vacuum that part first. And then I pull it down so as to vacuum the filter itself. Or when the prefilter becomes dirty, you can remove it completely, hand wash or machine wash (drip dry because I think it will shrink). You can slip on the spare one in the meanwhile. Make sure the prefilter is always pulled up and covering all parts of the main filter, as well as tucks underneath the bottom of the filter. All to prolong the life of the filter. I will be vacuuming 1-2 times a week. It's very dusty here and I have horrible allergies.
I do notice the air to be fresher when this has run for a few hours.
I'm still confused as to whether this has an ionizer or not. If so, it's always on. I wanted one that had no ionizer or the ability to switch it off, such as with the Holmes that I've used for years. But since I had some bad luck with my latest favorite Holmes, I decided to try something new, such as this Blue Pure 411.
Minor complaint, depending where it is located. I both like and dislike the touch-on button located at the very top. I like that it's a touch-on and with lights that display which of the 3 settings is running. But sometimes it doesn't touch-on easily, other times too easily. And if you set the purifier on the floor or a coffee table you can easily reach the touch-on and see which lights are on. But if you have it setting on taller furniture, as I do, I have to tip the purifier to see the lights and reach the touch-on. As I said, a minor complaint.
Time will tell how long this will last. I will report back later, if necessary. If it holds up and does the job, I'll raise it to a 5-star at that time.
Oh, if you are looking for the serial number. I was told by the company it is located underneath the fan, which is the touch-on section that sits on top the filter. I will need to remove the filter to get the s/n. So far I haven't done it.
Also, if you get an account and complete the Blue Pure warranty that comes with it, it will be extended up to 5 years. (Here in California anyway. Don't know about other states.) As with any warranty, it's wise, soon after you purchase, to jot down date of purchase, place of purchase, model and serial numbers.
I hope this helps answer any of your questions.

Data: So far so good, I did quite a bit of research prior to making this purchase. Pros-Easy set up pretty much plug and play. I like the idea of a washable filter I have a Honeywell 50250-s and an AeroMax 290 that are about 6 years old. I needed ones for other rooms, so I added these which are rated higher according to Consumer reports than my older ones, these are Wi-Fi compatible with a smooth easy set up once you download the app, and you can control them with Alexa and Siri I think if that is a feature you like. The app is relatively simple as far as making adjustments, to LED brightness and fan speed. There are 4 speeds, auto and night mode. It gives you the filters status. You can set a schedule. Generally, if you put it in auto, it will adjust according to the rooms needs and the night mode which I really like because it is super quiet and it's relatively close to my bed, and it has minimal lights. I thought about the Winix 5500, but it was actually rated lower than this by a significant amount and while other reviewers recommended it over the more expensive Coway I thought this was a good meeting in the middle especially during prime day. The Winix runs around $132-$155 while the Coway runs a bit higher about $339 at the time of my review. For prime day this was $199 so your mileage may vary as it typically might price at about $280. As for a comparison with my older purifiers the AeroMax still performs well it requires 2 filters be replaced, while this one has a washable filter and a replacement filter, which are reasonable affordable. With purifiers the gift that keeps giving is the filter replacement. I hope to one day find an affordable washable filter that I never have to replace, but for the companies where is the fun in that. If you are looking for a highly rated air purifier this would be my choice. For a bedroom the large seems too large, but mine does not have to work as hard to clear the air. My Honeywell is totally manual, so it's outdated compared to these and it's pretty loud on its lowest setting so we run it on high at night downstairs, while we can easily run these all day and night without really noticing. Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2023
Data:
I wanted an air purifier for my bedroom, so I settled on the Blue Air 411i.
I mostly went with this product because other reviews indicated it was good, and I particularly liked the low wattage & low noise. There are other similar models from Blue Air, and I sprung for the wifi-enabled "i" version. While I'm glad I opted for the "i" version, I also find it annoying that you need to pay extra for seemingly basic features like scheduling, which I don't believe is possible for the non-wifi version. That is, you can schedule the purifier to change modes & light settings on a custom schedule on the Blue Air app.
The Good:
- Quiet. On the lowest couple settings, it's inaudible to me unless I put my ear very close to it. If you crank it up to the highest settings, it's certainly audible. The specs say 18-46 dB. A very quiet room is probably 30-40 dB of ambient noise.
- Energy-efficient. I don't have a watt-meter, but the power specs state it's 20W (which I'm sure varies by the speed it's set to).
- Ability to turn lights off. You can turn the indicator lights completely off, so it's good for use in bedrooms.
The Bad:
- This is rather large for a placing in a bedroom. Dimensions are 18.9 X 10.6 X 10.6 in (H X W X D)
- Its circular design means that it's optimally placed without obstructions around it, which is not practical for most rooms. The Levoit Vital series air purifiers probably have a better design/form factor for bedrooms since they're designed to be pushed up against a wall.
- This is top-heavy and may be a tipping hazard. The bottom two-thirds or so of this product (where the air intake occurs) is basically empty space, while the business end of this is all on the top. The unit as a whole is not particularly heavy, so it' probably not a big deal if it does get knocked over, but a more stable base would've been nice.
- If you want the ability to program a schedule on this, you must pay the extra cash to get the wifi-enabled "i" version of this product. I have mine programmed to shut the lights off at night when I'm sleeping.
- The user interface of this thing is less than great. There are a couple touch buttons (that don't actually depress), and you have to use odd combinations of holding & pressing buttons to change the light brightness settings, and you have to cycle through the various speeds in a one-way direction. I understand a nicer interface would have required more buttons or a small screen, which is probably why they have the wifi version with an app which is much easier to use.
Also, the cost of the replacement filters should be taken into consideration when purchasing an air purifier. MSRP is $30 for two filters (though, 3rd party filters can be had for cheaper), and they recommend changing the filter every 6-9 months. There's also an indicator light that tells you when you're supposed to change the filter (though, I have no idea if it's based on time or air flow or both).
As a side note, the product I received from Amazon was defective. It would randomly shut off about once a day. It would basically behave as if it was unplugged, and I would have to unplug & re-plug it in to reset it (the power button wouldn't work). Blue Air support was good though. Friendly customer service, and they shipped me a replacement right away (before waiting to receive my defective unit & allowed me a couple weeks or maybe up to a month to ship it back & provided a postage-paid UPS label).

It’s in a studio under 220 square feet including bath, and the machine’s ideal room size is around 650 square feet. They say that at 650 square feet or so it should be clearing a full cycle of the room’s air in around 12 minutes, and I wanted it to clean the air ASAP without laboring for it. It’s always a good idea to go for a machine a bit stronger than you think you need.
Out of the box, the first thing I noticed was my asthma spiked up bigtime from it weeping intense VOCs, nearly hospitalizing me. It’s been running now for about 3 weeks, and that’s finally just beginning to fade.
My rescue inhaler consumption is through the roof, and my nose/sinuses are sealed shut and constantly gushing now… which shouldn’t be happening at this level of filtration. The air circulates in here so much now, I feel a breeze, and it’s ruffling my wall scrolls across the room. Serious air output.
The “smart” feature app doesn’t work with my iPhone. I tried several times, and it doesn’t want to connect or stay connected. I read their troubleshooting instructions, and even phoned their useless, rude tech support. I can tell you this much about it: it only monitors PM2.5, and the feature connecting to outdoor pollution monitoring by BreezoMeter doesn’t agree with BreezoMeter’s app set to my exact location… it’s claiming that the outdoor air quality is much better than it actually is. Meanwhile, it was claiming that my indoor air quality was excellent… as I was struggling in anaphylactic shock from my neighbors lighting up. Yep: still smelling the pot and cigarettes too.
I’m not the only one who is having problems with their app connecting at all, staying connected, and disagreeing with BreezoMeter’s app: they’re chronic problems that he majority of peoples reviews have been complaining about in the Apple App Store for years. Yes, years, and they’ve still not gotten it fixed. (Somewhat similar complaints to a slightly lesser degree in the Google Play store too-
I checked out of curiosity to see if it was only iOS users complaining.) So I have absolutely no access to any of the “smart” features, and the machine is 24/7 constantly blinking an annoying warning light, telling me that it’s failing to connect to the app.
Most of the time, the air quality indicator light on the machine is blue, claiming that the room has exceptional air quality, even when cooking. I’ve seen it go red twice for a couple of minutes when I had a hamburger cooking pan with mildly singed drippings in it. The burnt cooking smells take a long time to fade, including using the bathroom vent fan.
The dust being removed is very different from the dust my previous underpowered HEPA ionizer was removing: I now have a layer of dust quickly accumulating everywhere that I didn’t with the other machine, and strangely, it’s gritty and coarse in an immaculate room. My previous machine’s pre filter would become covered in thick, dense gray dust and have to be washed off every couple of weeks. This… after 3 weeks, it has a few specks of black lint from my bedding, visible if you look closely. That’s it. I’m noticing a huge difference in performance without the ionizer. 2 days post Swiffer detailing, I can swipe visible dust from the top of my desk and dresser with my hand. I can’t even figure out how that’s possible with this thing. There’s even a thick layer of fluffy toilet paper dust accumulating on the back of the toilet now, for the first time. I also go to the extreme measures of sealing entirely around the front door with blue painter’s tape to stop the shared air flow from the public hallway. That’s unfortunately been a way of life here for years… so you can’t say that it’s pulling in and filtering air from the hall.
Across the board, it has not been as advertised. A very expensive mistake that I’ve had absolutely no health benefits from so far.
•••••••••••••••••••••••••
ONE YEAR OF CONSTANT USE AT HIGHEST SETTING, + 1 filter replacement later:
The smart features never worked, which is a huge portion of the cost/value of the machine. It was the deciding factor for this purchase to begin with.
It also has a strange tendency to shut itself down completely for about a minute or so, then turn itself back on… though it’s not in automatic mode. A chip/electronic issue somewhere.
The machine is absolutely useless for thick second hand pot and cigarette smoke! It doesn’t even register the smoke, and says the pm2.5 is A-OK, ideal! Rarely does it think that anything is wrong with the air, in fact. Useless for mold- the room thickly reeks of it still! And ironically, it’s useless for dust too! A thick layer of dust settles in less than 24h after detailing the place top to bottom with a swiffer! The most visible dust it leaves behind on everything is what appears to be natural skin sheddings, which are dust mite food.
UPDATE 2: July 24th 2024
After strange indicator light behavior for a couple of weeks, all of the indicators are now dead. The colored light PM2.5 meter (which has never been trustworthy, and the app has never functioned with it) is now dark, along with all the lights on top of the machine that indicates that it’s running and and which speed. It’s now a very expensive fan with a filter medium over the top of it… and considering that it’s 100% electronics in there, it’s only a matter of time before the fan refuses to even run.
All in all, the worst HEPA filter machine I’ve ever owned… and the most expensive too!

Data:
I needed to set up a filter in my home office once I started sharing it with a parakeet, and decided to go for this model, as offering a good combination of size, appearance, and functionality. I also splurged on the 411i (internet connected) just to try it out.
I'm surprised at how much I'm enjoying the connectivity. Not that I NEED to be able to adjust fan speed from a thousand miles away, but I could!! More importantly, this gives me the ability to program a schedule - lower fan speed when I'm working, higher in the evenings / weekends. It also lets me set intermediate fan speeds, e.g. 2.5 versus 3, or whatever.
Noise: I have it set to 1 during the day, and I genuinely do not notice it unless I deliberately listen for it. When I'm in the office later, it is louder - but it's just white noise, so it's not bothersome. And my allergies do seem to be slightly better.
HEPA filtration: The manufacturer uses the term HEPASilent, not true HEPA. Doing some further reading, this is because the unit's filter is NOT a true HEPA filter, which by itself traps 99.7% of particles of 0.3 microns (and supposedly, even more for larger or smaller particles). Instead, this unit combines a barrier filter with an electrostatic unit - presumably this is responsible for the low noise level and the energy efficiency. Having used true HEPA units in the pasts, the BlueAir unit is definitely quieter.
Because of the electrostatic component, the device will emit a small amount of ozone. As it falls within all regulatory limits, including California's tough rules, this seems to be low enough that it is not worrisome. If you are particularly concerned over ozone, and/or plant to use this in a closed room without adequate ventilation, it's something to consider.
A note on the filtration efficiency: BlueAir claims that their unit removes 99.7% of particles 0.1 microns in size - which would seem to be even better than the HEPA standard. However, since the HEPA standard says that they will likely trap MORE particles larger and smaller than 0.3 microns, it is certainly possible that the BlueAir doesn't work quite as well. I don't know if that's the case, and I suspect that for household uses, it would not make any difference for practical purposes - the difference would be trivial.

1-8-2018 Ibought this filter based on the reviews of organizations and users alike, overall everyone was happy with varying levels of satisfaction. Here are the items that I have observed after one month of use. #1. The unit is very quiet and I was surprised upon opening it how simple the design is. It consists of the top fan assembly. The barrel filter with the activated charcoal filter inside and a simple frame that the filter is attached to with a cloth cover. Motor is connected by placing on top and turning a bit clockwise to lock the 2 together. #2 The entire unit is slightly larger than 2 gallon cubes of milk stacked one upon the other. (IE: It won't fit on a small nightstand or under a normal short bedside lamp. Also the unit should not be enclosed on a shelf as the air exhausts from the top and the intake is from the sides all around. I have mine on the floor beside the nightstand between the bed. #3. The outer cover actually acts as a pre-filter. Be prepared to do a quick hand wash of it every week (this will help your primary filter from being clogged with larger particles that can be caught in the fabric. My filter came with a blue and gray filter cover (the pre-filter) so I will trade then off every week and hand wash and hang dry the other one. #4. That being said there was some construction going on to a building next to ours and it smelled of burning and chemicals for just over a week. Afterward I looked at the filter (because I wash the outer filter every week.) and I saw honest truth to the filter being effective because the filter was extremely dirty. I tapped out the filter outside to remove some of the accumulated dust and debris. It still is working well. I expect I will have to replace it next month. But I would anticipate changing it out every three months because I do have strong allergies and my sleep has improved so much since it's use that it's a small price to pay. I will be getting a larger unit for the living area/office. Also happy to see that the replacement filters are not extremely expensive. I have seen some of the other mfr's filters that are 50+ for a filter for a unit that covers the same area and needed replaced every 3 to 6 months (which is what this says)
After a week of using it I questioned if it was doing any good. My roommate entered and commented how fresh the room smelled. So I started to think about when the last time I woke up in the middle of the night, which was a normal occurrence. Since I started using the unit I hadn't woke during that week. Also when I woke I felt much more rested. I have always had allergies and my roommates commented I would often snore loudly. Since I started using the filter constantly no snoring and have had a much more restful sleep. I have been very happy with this purchase. I will say that this unit is best for a Smaller room of up to 125 sq ft with standard 8' ceilings. aka 1000 cubic feet of space (LxWxH) which represents how much air the filter can process effectively. Beyond that it will be challenged to perform adequately. It is small enough that it could fit in a large suitcase and I would certainly take it if I were still traveling for work where I would spend a few weeks in a hotel room and then move to another location for another few weeks. A couple things to be aware of that I didn't initially understand.

I did some research and found this filter and decided to take the risk and try it out. I was worried about the price, but did the payment plan and it worked out great for me.
What I really love about this air filter is that it has a phone app. It shows the quality of your air and also the air outside so you can see the difference. I was able to see that the air quality in my house was “very bad quality.” After a couple days of moving the air filter around my house to make sure each room was getting filtered - I noticed a huge difference.
Another cool feature is that the filter goes on automatically when it detects something and continues to filter until the air is clean. At night time I put it into nighttime mode or just shut off.
Super easy to use and comes put together. All you have to do is take it out of the box and plug it in!

Data: I was forced to buy this unit to replace my original BlueAir 211 unit from 2016 which is still going strong. Sadly the manufacturer is no longer making replacement filters for the original units, although they will eventually have a metal cage and filter one can use. The newer unit was on sale via Amazon Prime Day so I picked one up to compare. The newer 211i Max unit is slightly larger than the older version. At maximum the sound is similar, but what is cool about the newer one is you can modify the fan speed in tiny increments to lower the sound and speed where the original unit only had 3 preset speeds. I'd say overall, the newer unit isn't as quiet as I'd hoped but is surely no louder than the original. The app says my air is "excellent" and as such if I toggle it to the Auto setting it puts the fan speed on the lowest setting. However, since I have allergies to dust and pollen, I decided to keep the fan at 60% (~the middle setting on the original) to ensure the air stays clean. I don't trust their ability to understand the air cleanliness in my home due to other reviewers saying they blew pollutants into the unit and it couldn't differentiate them. If I could trust it - it'd be a nice electricity savings as well as noise reduction. The app is OK - but not excellent as it is not intuitive (e.g., they show PMIs of 1, 2.5 and 10 but the list is only for show - I initially thought we could choose to toggle which PMI level we wanted to remove from the air). Overall I'd imagine the unit will perform as the original did, but no better, but I'd have preferred to keep the original rather than buy the new one. At least the Amazon Prime Day Deal took some of the sting out of the "upgrade".

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
Data:
The product details fail to mention that this product emits ozone, which is the primary ingredient in smog. No one in their right mind would install an ozone generator in their house. The box says it meets regulations for ozone emissions, but this has been shown by consumer reports to be inadequate for air purifiers which should run 24/7 (more information is available on their website's air purifier buying guide). It also claims to be 'so effective it reduces ozone', which is clearly a lie since the product emits ozone.
An air purifier should never add anything to the air - it should only remove contaminants. Adding a contaminant like ozone is unacceptable regardless of the volume generated. The ionization chamber needs to be removed for this to be a viable purifier.
It's really a shame that they botched this, as the product is otherwise very well designed.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2021
Data:
I have a cat with severe allergies that cause her to scratch herself bloody. I bought another air filter about a year ago, half the size and half the price of this one, and it significantly reduced her scratching. Just one problem: it only runs for 12 hours and then shuts itself off. I heard about this one, which can run 24/7, bought it on Prime Day and started running it as soon as it arrived.
I was very happy that it continued to run without interruption for three days, and my cat seemed fine. But on the morning of the third day I noticed that my cat was getting scratchy, as she usually gets if I forget to turn the 12 hour one back on (it's so quiet I sometimes don't notice when it turns off). I was appalled. I checked the device and the instructions to make sure I hadn't forgotten anything, made sure there wasn't any plastic covering the filter or a filter I didn't put in place, watched a video about setting it up, but everything seems to be in place. It just doesn't work as well as the one I already had for half the price.
I thought about returning it but I think I'm going to keep it here, on the other side of the room, as a backup for when I forget to turn the 12 hour one back on. Within about 10 minutes after I turned the old filter on, the cat seemed significantly less scratchy.
As for the noise level: I saw a lot of commercials that talked about how quiet this device is. On it's lowest level, it's very quiet, so quiet I was not even sure it was on, but I barely felt any air moving so I'm not sure it was doing anything. At the second level, it's a little bit louder but not at all troubling. At the highest level, it's loud enough to be very annoying. I kept it at the second level.

Data:
I initially really liked the Blue Air Pure 411. I even bought a couple more of the Auto models for additional rooms of the house. It seemed to do a good job, I could sleep just fine with the white noise of the highest speed, and it was easy to just run my vacuum's hose over the outer filter every couple of weeks to keep it clean.
After 6 months, the first one went bad, with red lights flashing, indicating it was time to change the filters. So I removed the inner (not a true HEPA) filter and outer filter and installed new ones, carefully reassembled the unit, plugged it back in and turned it on.
The red lights continue to flash, and the air coming out is full of a very fine dust. Almost as though they were on timers, the same thing happened with the other 2 units. The warranties are no longer in effect because I didn't purchase replacement filters often enough.
So now I have a few hundred dollars invested in units and replacement filters that don't work, and at best are good for target practice. I'm guessing none of the ratings companies (including CR, who I really trust) tested these things for more than a few days.
If you are only looking for a few months of use, this might be the filter for you. If you don't want to have to buy a new one every 3 to 6 months, you should find another brand.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2019
Data:
After years of waking up tired and congested, I decided to try an air purifier. I chose Blue Pure 411 for looks, size and cost of purchase and operations. I purchased one, which worked great, and then purchased 3 more. All 3 fans were defective and had clicking noise, more audible at low settings. I immediately returned 2 and the one I sent as gift to family apparently also has a slight clicking sound, so will be returning as well.
1st UNIT: Very happy with this first unit.
Pros:
- Super easy to setup and operate
- Worked great! Ran it on low mode all night and woke up with clear sinuses, so refreshed.
- Totally silent in "Low" mode. Mid and high modes are more audible but sound like white noise so depends on your noise sensitivity, Low setting seems to work great at night.
- Light weight, can easily be repositioned around the room.
- Simple and clean design.
- Affordable to purchase and replace filters ($20 on Amazon).
Cons:
- The lights did not turn off (decided to live with it).
2nd SET (Purchased 2 pack for other rooms and another single unit as a gift):
- All 3 fans were defective, had clicking noise. one unit was really bad and the other 2 are audible.
It is very disappointing when new products with great promise have such out of the box problems, quality should be controlled better!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2019
Data:
Unless size is your #1 concern, avoid this. Spend a bit more ($40 ish) to get something that's x5 times better. The fan on high is not something that you're going to want while occupying the room, it's loud and an annoying pitch. Med isn't much better but barely tolerable. A slightly larger unit will move much more air and do it with 0 audible/bothersome noise.
It's my understanding that most all of these filters get their room size/air flow rating on a high fan speed. Meaning if you run this on low and you have it in a closet is the only way it'll do what you'd expect. It's supposedly rated at 161 sq ft (161 sq ft = ~12 x 12ft) and cleaning that on low is a joke. If you need to put this on high you'll hate it, medium isn't great either. I wouldn't use this in anything bigger than an 8x8 space, maybe then low would do.
On low it's inaudible but the air flow is really low, you need to run med or high to really get anything out of it. And it's that small fan higher pitch annoying whine, don't keep it in a room that isn't loud already unless it's on low.
I use a 16" fan on high for white noise to sleep, love that. It's loud but a lower pitch and not annoying to me like this thing is.

Data: Overall I am unhappy with this product for the money spent. I wish I had instead gotten another 211+. My 211+ cranks air out even on the Stage 2 (Middle) setting. Stage 1 is impressively low power and pumps a little air through the room but I found it to be too little airflow to use. Maybe if I am gone for a week on vacation I'll use it, probably not. Stage 2 is better airflow but I still find it lacking for an 11x12 room (Kids room). This stage is what I end up using all of the time since Stage 3 gets to a level of noise that I find annoying. In Stage 3 (Max airflow) I find that the air is moving at a much more desirable level but I find the whining noise to be annoying so I can't handle actually keeping it on stage 3. Data:
We bought this unit because it was check rated by Consumer Reports. We have had it only a couple of weeks, so it is too early to judge performance.
There is a touch display that has the usual on/off and fan speed switches.
You can also toggle between three numbers: PM 1, PM 2.5, or PM 10. I think PM stands for “particulate matter”. I haven’t a clue what the numbers mean. The instruction booklet and website were no help. There is also a three digit display that currently says: zero. Zero what? It looks like this unit claims to have all kinds of sophisticated functions, and I question whether they really exist. Therefore three stars.
Two-month update: We have now had it for almost two months. The first month it was set at PM 2.5. The 2nd month I am running on PM 1 and can’t detect any difference. The 3rd month I’ll try PM 10. It has been on fan speed 2 the entire time. The display always shows “zero” and the blue light never changes.
All it does is draw air through a filter with a choice of four fan speeds. That’s it! Air cleaners that do this can be purchased for a third of what we paid for this unit.
One other possible source of information might be the Blueair app. I tried to set it up on my Galaxy 23, but couldn’t do it. The Bluetooth connection kept telling me to install the app which I had already done. That’s as far as I got.
A final mystery is why this item was check rated by Consumer Reports, which usually indicates a good combination of price and value.
Additional update: We purchased a Blueair 511 for a bedroom. It has one button and a choice of three fan speeds: just the basics. It cost about one third the cost of the 211. Therefore, if you are thinking of buying the 211, I recommend that you buy three 511’s for about the same amount of money and skip the numbers, colored lights, and gimmicks.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2023
Data:
Purchased to help out with allergies - specifically when sleeping. Bedroom is ~150 sq. ft. with 8 ft. ceiling.
Observations:
1). Getting initial wifi connection took nearly 30 mins. I am a heavy PC user by the way. And I have a degree in IS/IT. But after the initial connection issues it was solid.
2) The app would never provide current PM2.5 levels unless I shut down the app and restarted it.
3) Sensor is not very sensitive so the auto mode is useless unless air quality is very bad.
4) I ran a test where I lit half of an insence stick. After a full day of the unit running I could still smell the insence. Not impressive.
5) The purifier has 3 fan speeds selectible from the top. The app allows far more resolution of fan speeds which is nice. Above the 2nd setting the unit is very loud. Not just loud, but it's a very irritating type of white noise. I believe that's because of the high frequency content - but I didn't verify that wirh a spectrum analyzer. It's my perceived/subjective assessment. For example I have a large fan that is easily louder in terms of decibels, but it is a relaxing sound (like a hum) that helps sleeping.
6) I noticed very little change in the amount of dust settling on surfaces. And that's with forcing the unit to run on a higher setting than auto mode would select by itself. The reality is that this unit doesn't move much air.
I see two main use cases for this:
1) In a small-ish room, running it on the lowest speed (or close to) and placing it within a few feet of where you are - say at night.
2) In a larger space (maybe almost as large as what it's rated for) by running it on high while you are away (say at work) then slowing it down when you are home so it's not annoying.
It's a fine unit, but you just need to understand its limitations. It's for small volumes only in my opinion. I think a separate "stirring" fan would help bring air particles around so this unit could snag them. But then I think it makes more sense to just get a larger air purifier. Keep in mind a larger unit (albiet more expensive) has three big advantages:
1) It can clean the same volume of air as a smaller unit - but at a lower (read quieter) fan speed.
2) When necessary, it will be capable of cleaning a larger volume (pulling in from a greater distance).
3) It can clean the same volume of air as a smaller unit, but quicker.
Considering the experience I had, I returned mine because it simply didn't meet my needs. I purchased a much larger unit and will deal with the size. In the end I care more about the quality of my space than I do the decor.

Data:
2020 was a bad year for smoke here in the Bay Area of California from nearby fires, so we purchased one of these in 2021.
It is early in 2023 and we have used it since we got it. We have purchased a refill pleated finter and laundered the fabric prefilter twice--we have the third prefilter on the unit now, meaning one that has gone through the laundry once.
I have always preferred the filter being reuseable--one that can be cleaned and reused--but this has worked out well even as the filters are not inexpensive. The filtration is good, the prefilter works pretty well in slowing the accumulation of stuff from depositing on the main filter and forcing replacement.
We have it on most nights and in the winter it circulates and de-stratifies the air in our dining room almost as well as a ceiling fan would and since I prefer not to have something rotating above my head, this is adequate; it can put a narrow shaft of moving air right up to the ceiling without causing a draft if you position it near a corner of the room near a window.
It does not make too much noise in the medium setting and the high setting can really eliminate odors, dust, and temperature stratification fast.
We try to review things after using them for enough time for the enthusiasm for the "new" to wear off (as well as the buyer's remorse to deflate.

Data:
The Blue Pure 411 is compact, light and attractive. It comes with two colored (blue and black) washable bag-like pre-filters that fit around the outside of the main air filter. The main filter is a single combined particulate and carbon filter. Air is drawn in from all directions and expelled out the top. There's only one button, on the top of the purifier, surrounded by concentric lights that indicate the fan speed. Currently, there is no HEPA rating for this purifier although the combined filters seem more than capable of filtering out fine particulates.
There's three fan speeds. On the lowest speed it's practically silent. Medium speed has a whooshing white-noise sound, but it's low enough that you may be able to sleep with the purifier on. High speed is a small hurricane for when you want to clear the air fast; it's fairly loud and hard to ignore. Changing the filter is easy. When new, there is a slight new-thing smell with a hint of charcoal, which is probably coming from the filter. This may explain one of the reviews that claimed there was a burning smell. The smell has diminished after a couple days of use. But I wonder if the charcoal smell is normal for new filters? This seems odd.
The purifier remembers its last setting, so if the power goes out or you move it to another room it will start up at the same speed as it was last running.After using it for a few days, I'm happy to say it seems to clear the air quite nicely and my allergies have diminished.
There's two design flaws, however. First, the fan speed lights are bright enough to interfere with sleep. I read somewhere that they are supposed to 'dim' a few seconds after selecting a speed, but this isn't the case. I've started placing objects on top of the purifier to block the light. The second flaw is more serious. The single fan-speed button on top of the unit is attractive but not really a button. There's not detents or positive click feeling when you select a speed; it's more a matter of deforming the hard plastic cover to select a speed. I'm a strong guy and the amount of pressure it takes to change the fan speed is a bit alarming. Another reviewer commented that theirs did not work when new -- I suspect they simply weren't pressing the "button" hard enough. I have found that even pressure with the palm of my hand works better than pressing with a finger. A simple rotary knob would be much more usable (BLUEAIR, are you listening?). Now that I know how it works I don't have a problem, but you definitely don't want to buy this for an elderly person who can't muster that much effort.

The white piece is a housing that contains the power cord, the fan, and the touch activated button to turn the fan on and off. The base unit is a filter with a fabric pre-filter sleeve pulled over the top of it.
Easy to setup.
Quiet on all speeds except high.
Stylish and unobtrusive
Pre-filter is easy to clean
Seems to circulate air pretty well.
The Cons:
Unlike the larger models, the filter is not inserted into a plastic housing which the top fan piece connects to. Instead the filter actually connects directly to the fan unit.
Unlike the larger models, the pre-filter is actually stretched over the filter itself. You can feel the ribs of the filter under the fabric. This makes the whole thing feel less stable and definitely less sturdy. A swift kick from one of my kids or something hard bumping into it could easily dent the filter.
Other notes:
Kids think the touch panel is super cool to mess with, particularly my 1 year old. That means this thing rarely stays on the speed you set it at.
Because the default state for this is always off, you can’t connect it to any kind of smart plug. If you run it in a vacation house and that house loses power, it won’t come back on when power is restored.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2023
Data:
I bought this air purifier due to the Canada wildfires causing air quality issues in my area for the duration of summer- and because I live in an old apartment- for someone with respiratory problems this was a must. it definitely does its job quickly and effectively!
it senses changes in air quality fast- if I open a window nearby while the air is bad, the light flips to red and the fan starts running on high. it manages to clear the entirety of my 650 sqft apartment in minutes. I've even noticed it starts running a little harder after I use dry shampoo. it has five fan settings- auto (which changes fan speed depending on the air quality), night mode (does the same but quietly and therefore more slowly), and 3 set fan speeds. I included a video which hopefully shows noise level and fan power well. (please excuse my cat, she liked my tissue paper method)
setup was ridiculously easy. just plug it in, connect to the app, and it starts going at it. it is a bit large, but the design is modern and pleasing enough that it's not an eyesore. it's also not heavy at all, definitely less than 10lbs.
the app is also very convenient- you can control fan speed, schedule (if you want one), a child lock, and even the brightness of the LEDs. while away from home I can check in and see if there have been any spikes in poor quality air. blue air also has a wonderful feature that allows you to see the remaining lifetime of your filter. I believe the model I bought has an advertised lifetime of 6-9months, and after a full month of use on auto mode, I'm still at 93%.
the only negative I've noticed so far is not even really due to the purifier itself- the outside is fabric, which is turning out to be a very tempting scratching post for my cats. I believe the fabric can be replaced however so it's not really a big deal.
overall I really love this purifier, it's definitely made a difference in my breathing this summer!

Data: Received this as a gift from friends and was something we likely never would have purchased. An air purifier? Our air was fine. Turns out, the sensors had picked up a few specks of dust and was going on and off throughout the say. A quick blow in the back did the trick...that and changing the filter! Good luck...nice, super-quiet machine...
